theorem calculus_22795 {A : Matrix (Fin 2) (Fin 2) ℝ}
    (hA : A.det = 2) : (-3 * A).det = 18 := by

soln_description:
(a) Let $x$ and $y$ be two positive integers such that the difference between their squares is equal to 105, that is, $x^{2}-y^{2}=105$. Factoring, we get $(x-y)(x+y)=105$, and therefore, $x+y$ and $x-y$ must be divisors of 105, with $x+y > x-y$. Note that $1 \cdot 105 = 3 \cdot 35 = 5 \cdot 21 = 7 \cdot 15$ are all the ways to write the number 105 as a product of two positive integers. Thus, we have four cases:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
x+y=105 \\
x-y=1
\end{array} \Longleftrightarrow x=53 \text { and } y=52 .\right. \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
x+y=35 \\
x-y=3
\end{array} \Longleftrightarrow x=19 \text { and } y=16\right. \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
x+y=21 \\
x-y=5
\end{array} \Longleftrightarrow x=13 \text { and } y=8\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, it is possible to write 105 as the difference of two squares in four ways, namely: $53^{2}-52^{2}, 19^{2}-16^{2}, 13^{2}-8^{2}$, and $11^{2}-4^{2}$.

(b) Observe that for any integers $x$ and $y$, the numbers $x+y$ and $x-y$ are both even or both odd, since the sum of the two numbers is equal to $2x$, which is even, so we cannot have one even and the other odd.

From this, we conclude that the product $(x+y)(x-y)=x^{2}-y^{2}$ is a multiple of 4 (if $x+y$ and $x-y$ are even) or an odd number (if $x+y$ and $x-y$ are odd).

Since 106 is even but not divisible by 4, it cannot be written as the difference of two squares.

Facts that Help: The difference between the squares of two numbers is equal to the product of the sum of these numbers by the difference of the same numbers. Algebraically:

$$
m^{2}-n^{2}=(m+n)(m-n)
$$

Suggestion: Verify that the sequence that remains on the board after the entire process is periodic.

Facts that Help: A number and the sum of its digits leave the same remainder when divided by 9.
informal_statement:
(a) In how many ways can the number 105 be written as the difference of two perfect squares?

(b) Show that it is not possible to write the number 106 as the difference of two perfect squares.

##
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- (a) In how many ways can the number 105 be written as the difference of two perfect squares?

(b) Show that it is not possible to write the number 106 as the difference of two perfect squares.

## -/
theorem number_theory_252740 :
    {(x, y) : ℕ × ℕ | x^2 - y^2 = 105}.ncard = 4 ∧
    ¬∃ x y : ℕ, x^2 - y^2 = 106 := by

informal_statement: It is May now, $ 1 1 ^ { 4 0 3 8 } $ months later, which month will it be?
informal_proof:
We are given the problem of determining which month it will be after $11^{4038}$ months have passed, starting from May. This can be framed as a modular arithmetic problem. Let the months be numbered such that January is month 1, February is month 2, ..., May is month 5, and so on, up to December as month 12.

We need to calculate the month number corresponding to May plus $11^{4038}$ months. This is equivalent to computing $(5 + 11^{4038}) \pmod{12}$.

First, let's simplify the term $11^{4038} \pmod{12}$.
We observe that $11$ is congruent to $-1$ modulo $12$, since $11 = 12 - 1$.
So, $11 \equiv -1 \pmod{12}$.

Using the properties of modular arithmetic for exponentiation, we have:
$11^{4038} \equiv (-1)^{4038} \pmod{12}$.

Since the exponent $4038$ is an even number, $(-1)^{4038}$ is equal to $1$.
Therefore, $11^{4038} \equiv 1 \pmod{12}$.

Now, we substitute this result back into our original expression:
$(5 + 11^{4038}) \pmod{12} \equiv (5 + 1) \pmod{12}$.

Calculating the sum, we get:
$(5 + 1) \pmod{12} = 6 \pmod{12}$.

The result of the computation is $6$. This means that after $11^{4038}$ months have passed from May, it will be the 6th month of the year. The 6th month of the year is June.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- It is May now, $ 1 1 ^ { 4 0 3 8 } $ months later, which month will it be? -/
theorem number_theory_13597 : (11 ^ (4038) + 5) % 12 = 6 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_13597 : (11 ^ (4038) + 5) % 12 = 6 := by
  norm_num

soln_description:
$\triangle$ Let's find the last two digits of the first few terms of the sequence ($7^{n}$): $07,49,43,01,07,49,43,01,07,49, \ldots$.

From this, we can see that these digits repeat when the term number increases by 4, generally by $4k (k \in N)$. Since

$$
1995=4 \cdot 498 + 3
$$

the last two digits of $7^{1995}$ coincide with the last two digits of $7^{3}$, and therefore form the number 43. Answer: 43.
informal_statement: 218. Find the last two digits of the power $7^{1995}$.
informal_proof:
We want to find the last two digits of the number $7^{1995}$. This is equivalent to calculating the remainder when $7^{1995}$ is divided by 100.

We directly compute this value. The computation yields:
$$
7^{1995} \pmod{100} = 43
$$
Thus, the last two digits of $7^{1995}$ are 43.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 218. Find the last two digits of the power $7^{1995}$. -/
theorem number_theory_199976 : (7^1995) % 100 = 43 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_199976 : (7^1995) % 100 = 43 := by
  norm_num

soln_description:
Solution: Since $F(x, y)$ is the minimum of $2^{-x}, 2^{x-y}, 2^{y-1}$, $F(x, y)$ is not greater than the geometric mean of these three, i.e.,
$$
F(x, y) \leqslant \sqrt[3]{2^{-x} \times 2^{x-y} \times 2^{y-1}}=2^{-\frac{1}{3}} .
$$

When $x=\frac{1}{3}, y=\frac{2}{3}$, the equality holds, therefore, the maximum value of $F(x, y)$ is $2^{-\frac{1}{3}}$.
informal_statement:
Example 5 Given that $x, y$ are two variables in the interval $(0,1)$, denote the minimum value of $2^{-x}, 2^{x-y}, 2^{y-1}$ as $F(x, y)$. Find the maximum value of $F(x, y)$.
$(1984$, Shanghai Middle School Mathematics Competition)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Example 5 Given that $x, y$ are two variables in the interval $(0,1)$, denote the minimum value of $2^{-x}, 2^{x-y}, 2^{y-1}$ as $F(x, y)$. Find the maximum value of $F(x, y)$.
$(1984$, Shanghai Middle School Mathematics Competition) -/
theorem algebra_316192 (F : ℝ → ℝ → ℝ)
  (hF : F = λ x y => min (min (2 ^ (-x)) (2 ^ (x - y))) (2 ^ (y - 1))) :
  IsGreatest {z | ∃ x y : ℝ, x ∈ Ioo 0 1 ∧ y ∈ Ioo 0 1 ∧ F x y = z} (2 ^ (-1 / 3 : ℝ)) :=

soln_description:
1. **Lemma Statement and Proof:**
   - **Lemma:** Let \( p \) be an odd prime, \( m > 1 \), and \( m+1 \) is not divisible by \( p \). Then the number \( m^{p^k} + 1 \) has at least \( k \) distinct prime factors.
   - **Proof of Lemma:**
     - Assume \( p \mid m^{p^l} + 1 \). Then \( p \mid m^{2p^l} - 1 \).
     - This implies \( \text{ord}_p(m) \mid 2p^l \). Since \( \text{ord}_p(m) \mid p-1 \), we have \( \text{ord}_p(m) \mid \gcd(2p^l, p-1) = 1 \) or \( 2 \).
     - If \( \text{ord}_p(m) = 1 \), then \( p \mid m-1 \), which implies \( p \mid m^{p^l} - 1 \). But since \( p \mid m^{p^l} + 1 \), we get \( p \mid 2 \), a contradiction since \( p \) is odd.
     - If \( \text{ord}_p(m) = 2 \), then \( p \mid m^2 - 1 \). This implies \( p \mid m+1 \) (since \( p \mid m-1 \) would imply \( \text{ord}_p(m) = 1 \), a contradiction). But this is also a contradiction since we assumed \( m+1 \) is not divisible by \( p \).
     - Therefore, \( m^{p^l} + 1 \) is not divisible by \( p \).

2. **Proof of Lemma Continued:**
   - Consider \( m^{p^k} + 1 = (A + 1)(A^{p-1} - A^{p-2} + \cdots + 1) \) where \( A = m^{p^{k-1}} \).
   - Let \( d = \gcd(A + 1, A^{p-1} - A^{p-2} + \cdots + 1) \). Then \( A \equiv -1 \pmod{d} \).
   - Thus, \( A^{p-1} - A^{p-2} + \cdots + 1 \equiv p \pmod{d} \), hence \( d \mid p \).
   - From the above claim, \( A + 1 = m^{p^{k-1}} + 1 \) is not divisible by \( p \), so \( d = 1 \).
   - Therefore, \( A + 1 \) and \( A^{p-1} - A^{p-2} + \cdots + 1 \) are relatively prime.
   - This implies \( A^{p-1} - A^{p-2} + \cdots + 1 \) has at least one prime factor not in the prime factorization of \( A + 1 \).
   - By induction, applying the above proof \( k-1 \) times, we obtain \( m^{p^k} + 1 \) has at least \( k \) distinct prime factors.

3. **Main Proof:**
   - **Case 1:** \( m > 1 \)
     - Choose \( n = m^t \) for some \( t \).
     - Then \( m^n + n^m = m^{m^t} + m^{tm} = m^{tm}(m^{m^t - tm} + 1) = m^{tm}((m^m)^{m^{t-1} - t} + 1) \).
     - We need to show \( (m^m)^{m^{t-1} - t} + 1 \) has at least \( k \) distinct prime factors.
     - Choose \( t = p^k \) where \( p \) is an odd prime dividing \( m \). Then \( t-1 = p^k - 1 > k \).
     - Thus, \( p^k \mid m^{t-1} - t \) since \( p \mid m \).
     - Therefore, \( m^{t-1} - t = p^k w \) for some integer \( w \).
     - Hence, \( (m^m)^{m^{t-1} - t} + 1 = (m^{mw})^{p^k} + 1 \).
     - Since \( m^{mw} + 1 \equiv 1 \pmod{p} \) (as \( p \mid m \)), \( m^{mw} + 1 \) is not divisible by \( p \).
     - Applying the lemma, \( (m^{mw})^{p^k} + 1 \) has at least \( k \) distinct prime factors.

   - **Case 2:** \( m = 1 \)
     - Then \( m^n + n^m = 1 + n \).
     - Choose \( n = p_1 p_2 \cdots p_k - 1 \) where \( p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_k \) are distinct prime numbers.
     - Thus, \( 1 + n = p_1 p_2 \cdots p_k \), which has exactly \( k \) distinct prime factors.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: Let $k$ be a nonzero natural number and $m$ an odd natural number . Prove that there exist a natural number $n$ such that the number $m^n+n^m$ has at least $k$ distinct prime factors.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $k$ be a nonzero natural number and $m$ an odd natural number . Prove that there exist a natural number $n$ such that the number $m^n+n^m$ has at least $k$ distinct prime factors. -/
theorem number_theory_82643 (k m : ℕ) (hm : Odd m) (hk : k ≠ 0) :
    ∃ n : ℕ, (m ^ n + n ^ m).primeFactors.card ≥ k := by

informal_statement:
A differentiable function $f$ with $f(0) = f(1) = 0$ is defined on the interval $[0,1]$.
Prove that there exists a point $y \in  [0,1]$ such that $| f' (y)| = 4 \int _0^1 | f(x)|dx$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- A differentiable function $f$ with $f(0) = f(1) = 0$ is defined on the interval $[0,1]$.
Prove that there exists a point $y \in  [0,1]$ such that $| f' (y)| = 4 \int _0^1 | f(x)|dx$. -/
theorem calculus_82880 {f : ℝ → ℝ} (hf : DifferentiableOn ℝ f (Set.Icc 0 1))
    (h0 : f 0 = 0) (h1 : f 1 = 0) :
    ∃ y ∈ Set.Icc 0 1, |deriv f y| = 4 * ∫ x in (0)..1, |f x| := by

informal_statement: Let $f(x)$ be an odd function defined on $\mathbf{R}$, with $f(1)=2$. When $x<{}0$, $f(x)$ is an increasing function, and for any $x,y\in \mathbf{R}$, $f(x+y)=f(x)+f(y)$. Then the maximum value of the function $f(x)$ on the interval [-3,-2] is ___          ___ .
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $f(x)$ be an odd function defined on $\mathbf{R}$, with $f(1)=2$. When $x<{}0$, $f(x)$ is an increasing function, and for any $x,y\in \mathbf{R}$, $f(x+y)=f(x)+f(y)$. Then the maximum value of the function $f(x)$ on the interval [-3,-2] is ___          ___ . -/
theorem algebra_11640 (f : ℝ → ℝ)
    (hodd : ∀ x, f (-x) = -f x)
    (hf1 : f 1 = 2)
    (hfinc : ∀ x < 0, deriv f x > 0)
    (hfadd : ∀ x y, f (x + y) = f x + f y) :
    IsGreatest (Set.image f (Set.Icc (-3) (-2))) (-4) := by

soln_description:
[Proof] (1) Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}$ be $n$ integers, and satisfy the conditions:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}=0 \\
a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}=n
\end{array}
$$

If $n$ is odd, then by (2), all factors $a_{i}(i=1,2, \cdots, n)$ are odd. The sum of an odd number of odd numbers should be odd, and cannot be 0, which contradicts (1).
Therefore, $n$ must be even.
When $n$ is even, then by (2), there must be one $a_{j}$ that is even. By (1), there must be at least one more even number, otherwise the sum of an odd number of odd numbers and one even number cannot equal 0.
Thus, there must be at least two even numbers among $a_{i}$. By (2), $n$ must be divisible by 4.
(2) Let $n$ be a multiple of 4, and $n=4 k, \quad k \in N$.
When $k$ is odd,
$$
n=2 \cdot(-2 k) \cdot 1^{3 k-2} \cdot(-1)^{k} \text {. }
$$

Since $2+(-2 k)+\underbrace{1+\cdots+1}_{(3 k-2) \uparrow}+\underbrace{(-1)+\cdots+(-1)}_{k \uparrow}$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
=2-2 k+3 k-2-k \\
=0 .
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, we can choose 1 number 2, 1 number $-2 k$, $3 k-2$ numbers 1, and $k$ numbers -1, these $4 k$ numbers satisfy the requirements.
When $k$ is even,
$$
n=(-2) \cdot(-2 k) \cdot 1^{3 k} \cdot(-1)^{k-2} .
$$

Since
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (-2)+(-2 k)+\underbrace{1+\cdots+1}_{3 k \uparrow}+\underbrace{(-1)+\cdots+(-1)}_{(k-2) \uparrow} \\
= & -2-2 k+3 k+2-k \\
= & 0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, we can choose 1 number $-2$, 1 number $-2 k$, $3 k$ numbers 1, and $k-2$ numbers -1, these $4 k$ numbers satisfy the requirements.
informal_statement:
$7 \cdot 33$ (1) There are $n$ integers, whose product is $n$, and whose sum is 0. Prove that the number $n$ is divisible by 4.
(2) Let $n$ be a natural number divisible by 4. Prove that it is possible to find $n$ integers, whose product is $n$, and whose sum is 0.
(18th All-Soviet Union Mathematical Olympiad, 1984)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $7 \cdot 33$ (1) There are $n$ integers, whose product is $n$, and whose sum is 0. Prove that the number $n$ is divisible by 4.
(2) Let $n$ be a natural number divisible by 4. Prove that it is possible to find $n$ integers, whose product is $n$, and whose sum is 0.
(18th All-Soviet Union Mathematical Olympiad, 1984) -/
theorem number_theory_105143 {n : ℕ} (hn : n > 0) (a : Fin n → ℤ)
    (h₀ : ∏ i, a i = n) (h₁ : ∑ i, a i = 0) :
    4 ∣ n := by

soln_description:
From (a), we have
$$
a_{n}-a_{n+1}=\frac{b_{n-1}}{b_{n+1}}\left(a_{n-1}-a_{n}\right),
$$

thus
$$
a_{n}-a_{n+1}=\frac{b_{0} b_{1}}{b_{n} b_{n+1}}\left(a_{0}-a_{1}\right) .
$$

If $a_{1}=a_{0}=1$, then $a_{n}=1$.
If $a_{1}a_{0}-a_{n}=b_{0} b_{1}\left(a_{0}-a_{1}\right) \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} \frac{1}{b_{k} b_{k+1}},
$$

this implies
$$
\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} \frac{1}{b_{k} b_{k+1}}<\frac{a_{0}}{b_{0} b_{1}\left(a_{0}-a_{1}\right)} .
$$

Let $x_{n}=\sqrt{b_{n} b_{n+1}}$, then
$$
\begin{aligned}
x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n} & \leqslant \frac{b_{1}+b_{2}}{2}+\frac{b_{2}+b_{3}}{2}+\cdots+\frac{b_{n}+b_{n+1}}{2} \\
& <b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n+1} \leqslant(n+1)^{\frac{3}{2}} \leqslant 4 n^{\frac{3}{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

For any positive integer $k$,
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{k}{\frac{1}{x_{k+1}^{2}}+\frac{1}{x_{k+2}^{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{x_{2 k}^{2}}} & \leqslant \sqrt[k]{x_{k+1}^{2} \cdots x_{2 k}^{2}} \leqslant\left(\frac{x_{k+1}+\cdots+x_{2 k}}{k}\right)^{2} \\
& <\frac{\left(4(2 k)^{\frac{3}{2}}\right)^{2}}{k^{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

This implies
$$
\frac{1}{x_{k+1}^{2}}+\frac{1}{x_{k+2}^{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{x_{2 k}^{2}} \geqslant \frac{1}{2^{7}} .
$$

Thus $\sum_{k=0}^{2^{*}} \frac{1}{b_{k} b_{k+1}} \geqslant \frac{n}{2^{7}}$. This contradicts $(* *)$. This shows that $a_{n}=1, n \geqslant 0$.
informal_statement:
+ Let two positive sequences $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ and $\left\{b_{n}\right\}$ satisfy:
(a) $a_{0}=1 \geqslant a_{1}$, $a_{n}\left(b_{n-1}+b_{n+1}\right)=a_{n-1} b_{n-1}+a_{n+1} b_{n+1}, n \geqslant 1 ;$
(b) $\sum_{i=0}^{n} b_{i} \leqslant n^{\frac{3}{2}}, n \geqslant 1$,

Find the general term of $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- + Let two positive sequences $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ and $\left\{b_{n}\right\}$ satisfy:
(a) $a_{0}=1 \geqslant a_{1}$, $a_{n}\left(b_{n-1}+b_{n+1}\right)=a_{n-1} b_{n-1}+a_{n+1} b_{n+1}, n \geqslant 1 ;$
(b) $\sum_{i=0}^{n} b_{i} \leqslant n^{\frac{3}{2}}, n \geqslant 1$,

Find the general term of $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$. -/
theorem algebra_228948 {a b : ℕ → ℝ} (ha0 : a 0 = 1) (hpos : ∀ n, a n > 0 ∧ b n > 0)
    (h0 : a 0 ≥ a 1) (h : ∀ n ≥ 1, a n * (b (n - 1) + b (n + 1)) = a (n - 1) * b (n - 1) + a (n + 1) * b (n + 1))
    (hb : ∀ n ≥ 1, ∑ i in Finset.Icc 0 n, b i ≤ n ^ (3 / 2)) :
    ∀ n, a n = 1 := by

soln_description:
To prove the statement, we need to show two directions: sufficiency and necessity.

### Sufficiency
Assume that $\gcd(ab, m) = \gcd(b, m)$. Let $\gcd(b, m) = k$. Then we can write $b = k \cdot b_1$ and $m = k \cdot m_1$ where $\gcd(b_1, m_1) = 1$.

We need to show that there exists a positive integer $n$ such that $(a^n - 1)b$ is divisible by $m$. This is equivalent to showing that:
\[
m \mid (a^n - 1)b \quad \text{or} \quad k \cdot m_1 \mid (a^n - 1) \cdot k \cdot b_1
\]
Simplifying, we get:
\[
m_1 \mid (a^n - 1) \cdot b_1
\]
Since $\gcd(b_1, m_1) = 1$, it suffices to show that:
\[
m_1 \mid a^n - 1
\]
Given $\gcd(ab, m) = \gcd(b, m)$, we have $\gcd(a, m_1) = 1$. By Euler's theorem, since $\gcd(a, m_1) = 1$, we know that:
\[
a^{\phi(m_1)} \equiv 1 \pmod{m_1}
\]
Thus, taking $n = \phi(m_1)$, we have:
\[
a^n \equiv 1 \pmod{m_1}
\]
Therefore, $m_1 \mid a^n - 1$, and hence $(a^n - 1)b$ is divisible by $m$. This completes the sufficiency part.

### Necessity
Assume that there exists a positive integer $n$ such that $(a^n - 1)b$ is divisible by $m$. This means:
\[
m \mid (a^n - 1)b
\]
Let $\gcd(b, m) = k$. Then $m = k \cdot m_1$ and $b = k \cdot b_1$ where $\gcd(b_1, m_1) = 1$. We need to show that $\gcd(ab, m) = \gcd(b, m)$.

Since $m \mid (a^n - 1)b$, we have:
\[
k \cdot m_1 \mid (a^n - 1) \cdot k \cdot b_1
\]
Simplifying, we get:
\[
m_1 \mid (a^n - 1) \cdot b_1
\]
Since $\gcd(b_1, m_1) = 1$, it follows that:
\[
m_1 \mid a^n - 1
\]
This implies that $a^n \equiv 1 \pmod{m_1}$. Therefore, $\gcd(a, m_1) = 1$ because if $\gcd(a, m_1) \neq 1$, then $a^n \equiv 1 \pmod{m_1}$ would be impossible for any $n$.

Thus, $\gcd(a, m_1) = 1$ implies that $\gcd(ab, m) = \gcd(b, m)$. This completes the necessity part.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: Let $ a$, $ b$ and $ m$ be positive integers. Prove that there exists a positive integer $ n$ such that $ (a^n \minus{} 1)b$ is divisible by $ m$ if and only if $ \gcd (ab, m) \equal{} \gcd (b, m)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $ a$, $ b$ and $ m$ be positive integers. Prove that there exists a positive integer $ n$ such that $ (a^n \minus{} 1)b$ is divisible by $ m$ if and only if $ \gcd (ab, m) \equal{} \gcd (b, m)$. -/
theorem number_theory_75096 (a b m : ℕ) (_ : 0 < a) (h₀ : 0 < b) (h₁ : 0 < m) :
    ∃ n : ℕ, 0 < n ∧ m ∣ (a ^ n - 1) * b ↔ Nat.gcd (a * b) m = Nat.gcd b m := by

soln_description:
To determine all 4-tuples \((a, b, c, d)\) of real numbers that solve the given system of equations, we start by analyzing each equation individually and then look for common solutions.

The system of equations is:
\[
\begin{cases}
ab + ac = 3b + 3c \\
bc + bd = 5c + 5d \\
ac + cd = 7a + 7d \\
ad + bd = 9a + 9b 
\end{cases}
\]

1. **First Equation:**
   \[
   ab + ac = 3b + 3c
   \]
   Factor out common terms:
   \[
   a(b + c) = 3(b + c)
   \]
   If \(b + c \neq 0\), we can divide both sides by \(b + c\):
   \[
   a = 3
   \]
   If \(b + c = 0\), then \(b = -c\).

2. **Second Equation:**
   \[
   bc + bd = 5c + 5d
   \]
   Factor out common terms:
   \[
   b(c + d) = 5(c + d)
   \]
   If \(c + d \neq 0\), we can divide both sides by \(c + d\):
   \[
   b = 5
   \]
   If \(c + d = 0\), then \(c = -d\).

3. **Third Equation:**
   \[
   ac + cd = 7a + 7d
   \]
   Factor out common terms:
   \[
   c(a + d) = 7(a + d)
   \]
   If \(a + d \neq 0\), we can divide both sides by \(a + d\):
   \[
   c = 7
   \]
   If \(a + d = 0\), then \(a = -d\).

4. **Fourth Equation:**
   \[
   ad + bd = 9a + 9b
   \]
   Factor out common terms:
   \[
   d(a + b) = 9(a + b)
   \]
   If \(a + b \neq 0\), we can divide both sides by \(a + b\):
   \[
   d = 9
   \]
   If \(a + b = 0\), then \(a = -b\).

Now, we need to check the consistency of these solutions:

- If \(a = 3\), \(b = 5\), \(c = 7\), and \(d = 9\), we substitute these values into the original equations to verify:
  \[
  \begin{cases}
  3 \cdot 5 + 3 \cdot 7 = 15 + 21 = 36 \quad \text{and} \quad 3 \cdot (5 + 7) = 3 \cdot 12 = 36 \\
  5 \cdot 7 + 5 \cdot 9 = 35 + 45 = 80 \quad \text{and} \quad 5 \cdot (7 + 9) = 5 \cdot 16 = 80 \\
  3 \cdot 7 + 7 \cdot 9 = 21 + 63 = 84 \quad \text{and} \quad 7 \cdot (3 + 9) = 7 \cdot 12 = 84 \\
  3 \cdot 9 + 5 \cdot 9 = 27 + 45 = 72 \quad \text{and} \quad 9 \cdot (3 + 5) = 9 \cdot 8 = 72 
  \end{cases}
  \]
  All equations are satisfied, so \((3, 5, 7, 9)\) is a solution.

- If \(a = t\), \(b = -t\), \(c = t\), and \(d = -t\), we substitute these values into the original equations to verify:
  \[
  \begin{cases}
  t(-t) + t(t) = -t^2 + t^2 = 0 \quad \text{and} \quad 3(-t) + 3t = -3t + 3t = 0 \\
  (-t)t + (-t)(-t) = -t^2 + t^2 = 0 \quad \text{and} \quad 5t + 5(-t) = 5t - 5t = 0 \\
  t(t) + t(-t) = t^2 - t^2 = 0 \quad \text{and} \quad 7t + 7(-t) = 7t - 7t = 0 \\
  t(-t) + (-t)(-t) = -t^2 + t^2 = 0 \quad \text{and} \quad 9t + 9(-t) = 9t - 9t = 0 
  \end{cases}
  \]
  All equations are satisfied, so \((t, -t, t, -t)\) is a solution for any \(t \in \mathbb{R}\).

The final answer is \( \boxed{ (3, 5, 7, 9) } \) and \((t, -t, t, -t)\) for any \(t \in \mathbb{R}\).
informal_statement:
You can determine all 4-ples $(a,b, c,d)$ of real numbers, which solve the following equation system $\begin{cases} ab + ac = 3b + 3c \\
bc + bd = 5c + 5d \\
ac + cd = 7a + 7d \\
ad + bd = 9a + 9b \end{cases} $
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- You can determine all 4-ples $(a,b, c,d)$ of real numbers, which solve the following equation system $\begin{cases} ab + ac = 3b + 3c \\
bc + bd = 5c + 5d \\
ac + cd = 7a + 7d \\
ad + bd = 9a + 9b \end{cases} $
 -/
theorem algebra_82360 (a b c d : ℝ) :
    a * b + a * c = 3 * b + 3 * c ∧
    b * c + b * d = 5 * c + 5 * d ∧
    a * c + c * d = 7 * a + 7 * d ∧
    a * d + b * d = 9 * a + 9 * b ↔
    (a, b, c, d) = (3, 5, 7, 9) := by

soln_description:
5. Since $p^{a}+q^{b}$ is an odd number, at least one of the numbers $p$ and $q$ is even, and it must be equal to 2.
(i) Let $q=2$. Then $19-b \mid 19^{a}-p^{a}=2^{b}$, so $19-p$ is a power of two, i.e., $p \in\{3,11,17\}$. According to the problem, only $p=17$ is possible.

If $2 \mid a$, then $19^{2}-17^{2}=72$ divides $19^{a}-17^{a}=2^{b}$, which is impossible. On the other hand, if $2 \nmid a$, then $2^{b-1}=\frac{19^{a}-17^{a}}{19-17}=\sum_{i=0}^{a-1} 19^{a-1-i} 17^{i}$ is odd, which is possible only for $b=a=1$. Therefore, in this case, the only solution is $(p, q, a, b)=(17,2,1,1)$.

(ii) Let $p=2$. Then $q^{b}=19^{a}-2^{a}=17 C$, where $C=\sum_{i=0}^{a-1} 19^{i} 2^{a-1-i}$. From this, it follows that $q=17$ and $C=17^{k}$ for some $k \in \mathbb{N}_{0}$.

For $a=1$, we get the solution $(p, q, a, b)=(2,17,1,1)$. Let $a>1$. Then $17 \mid C$. On the other hand, since $19^{i} \equiv 2^{i}(\bmod 17)$, we have $C \equiv$ $\sum_{i=0}^{a-1} 2^{i} 2^{a-1-i}=a \cdot 2^{a-1}(\bmod 17)$, from which it follows that $17 \mid a$. Therefore, $19^{a}-2^{a}$ is divisible by $D=19^{17}-2^{17}$. However, $D=(2+17)^{17}-2^{17}=$ $\sum_{i=0}^{17}\binom{17}{i} 2^{17-i} 17^{i}-2^{17}=\sum_{i=1}^{17}\binom{17}{i} 2^{17-i} 17^{i} \equiv\binom{17}{1} 2^{16} \cdot 17\left(\bmod 17^{3}\right)$, as all other terms are divisible by $17^{3}$. Therefore, $D$ is not divisible by $17^{3}$, but $D>17^{2}$, so $D$ cannot be a power of 17. It follows that there are no solutions for $a>1$.

Therefore, the only solutions $(p, q, a, b)$ are $(2,17,1,1)$ and $(17,2,1,1)$.
informal_statement:
5. Find all natural numbers $a$ and $b$ and prime numbers $p$ and $q$ such that at least one of the numbers $p$ and $q$ is greater than 12 and the following holds:

$$
p^{a}+q^{b}=19^{a}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5. Find all natural numbers $a$ and $b$ and prime numbers $p$ and $q$ such that at least one of the numbers $p$ and $q$ is greater than 12 and the following holds:

$$
p^{a}+q^{b}=19^{a}
$$ -/
theorem number_theory_112617 (a b p q : ℕ) (ha : a > 0) (hb : b > 0)
    (hp : p.Prime) (hq : q.Prime) (h : p^a + q^b = 19^a) :
    (p > 12 ∨ q > 12) ↔ (p = 2 ∧ q = 17 ∧ a = 1 ∧ b = 1) ∨
    (p = 17 ∧ q = 2 ∧ a = 1 ∧ b = 1) := by

soln_description:
Solution. We can write the condition as $a_{n}-2=a_{0} a_{1} \cdot \ldots \cdot a_{n-1}$. From this, $a_{n-1}-2=a_{0} a_{1} \ldots \cdot a_{n-2}$. Then, we have $a_{n-1}\left(a_{n-1}-2\right)=a_{n}-2$ from which $a_{n-1}^{2}-2 a_{n-1}=a_{n}-2$. The latter is equivalent to $\left(a_{n-1}-1\right)^{2}=a_{n}-1$. Then,

$a_{n}-1=\left(a_{n-1}-1\right)^{2}=\left(a_{n-2}-1\right)^{4}=\ldots=\left(a_{n-k}-1\right)^{2^{k}}=\left(a_{0}-1\right)^{2^{n}}=2^{2^{n}}$.

Finally, we get $a_{2013}=2^{2^{2013}}+1$.
informal_statement: 4A. Let the sequence $\left(a_{n}\right)$ be defined by $a_{0}=3$ and $a_{n}=2+a_{0} a_{1} \cdot \ldots \cdot a_{n-1}$ for every $n \geq 1$. Find the term $a_{2013}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4A. Let the sequence $\left(a_{n}\right)$ be defined by $a_{0}=3$ and $a_{n}=2+a_{0} a_{1} \cdot \ldots \cdot a_{n-1}$ for every $n \geq 1$. Find the term $a_{2013}$. -/
theorem number_theory_254775 (a : ℕ → ℕ)
    (h₀ : a 0 = 3)
    (h₁ : ∀ n ≥ 1, a n = 2 + ∏ i ∈ Finset.range n, a i) :
    a 2013 = 2 ^ (2 ^ 2013) + 1 := by

soln_description:
1. Given the polynomial equation:
   \[
   c_4z^4 + ic_3z^3 + c_2z^2 + ic_1z + c_0 = 0
   \]
   where \( z = a + bi \) is a solution, and \( c_0, c_1, c_2, c_3, c_4, a, \) and \( b \) are real constants.

2. To find another solution, we take the complex conjugate of both sides of the equation. Recall that the complex conjugate of \( z = a + bi \) is \( \overline{z} = a - bi \), and the conjugate of \( i \) is \( -i \).

3. Taking the conjugate of the entire polynomial equation:
   \[
   \overline{c_4z^4 + ic_3z^3 + c_2z^2 + ic_1z + c_0} = 0
   \]
   Using the properties of conjugates, we get:
   \[
   c_4 \overline{z^4} + \overline{i} c_3 \overline{z^3} + c_2 \overline{z^2} + \overline{i} c_1 \overline{z} + c_0 = 0
   \]
   Since \( \overline{i} = -i \), this simplifies to:
   \[
   c_4 \overline{z}^4 - i c_3 \overline{z}^3 + c_2 \overline{z}^2 - i c_1 \overline{z} + c_0 = 0
   \]

4. Substitute \( \overline{z} = a - bi \):
   \[
   c_4 (a - bi)^4 - i c_3 (a - bi)^3 + c_2 (a - bi)^2 - i c_1 (a - bi) + c_0 = 0
   \]

5. Now, consider the polynomial with \( -\overline{z} \):
   \[
   -\overline{z} = -(a - bi) = -a + bi
   \]
   Substitute \( -\overline{z} \) into the original polynomial:
   \[
   c_4 (-\overline{z})^4 + i c_3 (-\overline{z})^3 + c_2 (-\overline{z})^2 + i c_1 (-\overline{z}) + c_0 = 0
   \]
   Simplifying, we get:
   \[
   c_4 (-a + bi)^4 + i c_3 (-a + bi)^3 + c_2 (-a + bi)^2 + i c_1 (-a + bi) + c_0 = 0
   \]

6. Therefore, if \( z = a + bi \) is a root, then \( -\overline{z} = -a + bi \) must also be a root.

Conclusion:
\[
\boxed{\textbf{(C)} -a + bi}
\]
informal_statement:
Suppose $z=a+bi$ is a solution of the polynomial equation $c_4z^4+ic_3z^3+c_2z^2+ic_1z+c_0=0$, where $c_0$, $c_1$, $c_2$, $c_3$, $a$, and $b$ are real constants and $i^2=-1$. Which of the following must also be a solution? 

$\textbf{(A) } -a-bi\qquad \textbf{(B) } a-bi\qquad \textbf{(C) } -a+bi\qquad \textbf{(D) }b+ai \qquad \textbf{(E) } \text{none of these}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Suppose $z=a+bi$ is a solution of the polynomial equation $c_4z^4+ic_3z^3+c_2z^2+ic_1z+c_0=0$, where $c_0$, $c_1$, $c_2$, $c_3$, $a$, and $b$ are real constants and $i^2=-1$. Which of the following must also be a solution? 

$\textbf{(A) } -a-bi\qquad \textbf{(B) } a-bi\qquad \textbf{(C) } -a+bi\qquad \textbf{(D) }b+ai \qquad \textbf{(E) } \text{none of these}$ -/
theorem algebra_81302 {c : ℕ → ℝ} {z : ℂ} (hz : c 4 * z ^ 4 + I * c 3 * z ^ 3 + c 2 * z ^ 2 + I * c 1 * z + c 0 = 0)
    (a b : ℝ) (ha : z.re = a) (hb : z.im = b) :
    c 4 * (-a + b * I) ^ 4 + I * c 3 * (-a + b * I) ^ 3 + c 2 * (-a + b * I) ^ 2 + I * c 1 * (-a + b * I) + c 0 = 0 := by

informal_statement:
Let $f \in C^2(\mathbb{R})$. Suppose that for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$, the following conditions hold:
\[ |f(x)|^2 \le a \]
\[ |f'(x)|^2 + |f''(x)|^2 \le b \]
where $a$ and $b$ are positive constants. Prove that for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$,
\[ |f(x)|^2 + |f'(x)|^2 \le \max(a, b) \]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib
open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Let $f \in C^2(\mathbb{R})$. Suppose that for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$, the following conditions hold:
\[ |f(x)|^2 \le a \]
\[ |f'(x)|^2 + |f''(x)|^2 \le b \]
where $a$ and $b$ are positive constants. Prove that for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$,
\[ |f(x)|^2 + |f'(x)|^2 \le \max(a, b) \] -/
theorem calculus_2122 {f : ℝ → ℝ} (hf : ContDiff ℝ 2 f)
  (a b : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b)
  (h₁ : ∀ x, |f x| ^ 2 ≤ a)
  (h₂ : ∀ x, |deriv f x| ^ 2 + |deriv (deriv f) x| ^ 2 ≤ b) :
  ∀ x, |f x| ^ 2 + |deriv f x| ^ 2 ≤ max a b := by

informal_statement: 3. For which integers $b$, is the congruence equation $7 x^{8} \equiv b(\bmod 41)$ solvable?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. For which integers $b$, is the congruence equation $7 x^{8} \equiv b(\bmod 41)$ solvable? -/
theorem number_theory_6601 :
    {b : ℤ | ∃ x, 7 * x ^ 8 ≡ b [ZMOD 41]} = {29, 3, 30, 13, 7} := by

informal_statement: Let $f(z)$ be a function that is holomorphic in the complex plane $\mathbb{C}$. Suppose there exists a disc $D(a, r)$ with center $a$ and radius $r$ such that $f(z) \notin D(a, r)$ for any $z \in \mathbb{C}$. Prove that $f$ must be a constant function.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Complex Filter Function Metric Finset
open scoped BigOperators Topology

/- Let $f(z)$ be a function that is holomorphic in the complex plane $\mathbb{C}$. Suppose there exists a disc $D(a, r)$ with center $a$ and radius $r$ such that $f(z) \notin D(a, r)$ for any $z \in \mathbb{C}$. Prove that $f$ must be a constant function. -/
theorem algebra_4780 {f : ℂ → ℂ} (hf : Differentiable ℂ f)
(h : ∃ a r, ∀ z, f z ∉ ball a r) :
∃ c, f = λ _ => c := by

informal_statement:
Find the smallest positive integer $N$ that satisfies the conditions that the remainder when $N$ is divided by $7$ is $5$, and the remainder when $N$ is divided by $17$ is $10$.

Find the smallest positive integer $N$ that satisfies the conditions that the remainder when $N$ is divided by $7$ is $5$, and the remainder when $N$ is divided by $17$ is $10$.
informal_proof:
We want to show that $61$ is the smallest positive integer $N$ such that $N \equiv 5 \pmod{7}$ and $N \equiv 10 \pmod{17}$.

First, we verify that $61$ satisfies these conditions:
1.  $61$ is positive, since $61 > 0$.
2.  The remainder of $61$ when divided by $7$ is $5$.
3.  The remainder of $61$ when divided by $17$ is $10$.
Thus, $61$ belongs to the set of integers satisfying the given conditions.

Next, we demonstrate that $61$ is the smallest such integer. We proceed by contradiction. Assume there exists a positive integer $N$ such that $N \equiv 5 \pmod{7}$ and $N \equiv 10 \pmod{17}$, and $N < 61$.

By considering all integers $N$ such that $0 \le N < 61$, and applying the given congruence conditions, we find that no integer in this range satisfies both $N \equiv 5 \pmod{7}$ and $N \equiv 10 \pmod{17}$ simultaneously. This contradiction shows that our assumption is false.

Therefore, $61$ is the least positive integer satisfying both congruence relations.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find the smallest positive integer $N$ that satisfies the conditions that the remainder when $N$ is divided by $7$ is $5$, and the remainder when $N$ is divided by $17$ is $10$.

Find the smallest positive integer $N$ that satisfies the conditions that the remainder when $N$ is divided by $7$ is $5$, and the remainder when $N$ is divided by $17$ is $10$. -/
theorem number_theory_5170 : IsLeast {N | 0 < N ∧ N % 7 = 5 ∧ N % 17 = 10} 61 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_5170 : IsLeast {N | 0 < N ∧ N % 7 = 5 ∧ N % 17 = 10} 61 := by
  constructor
  · -- Show 61 is in the set
    constructor
    · norm_num -- 61 > 0
    constructor
    · norm_num -- 61 % 7 = 5
    · norm_num -- 61 % 17 = 10

  · -- Show 61 is the smallest
    intro N hN
    rcases hN with ⟨hN_pos, hN_mod7, hN_mod17⟩
    by_contra h
    push_neg at h
    interval_cases N <;> omega

soln_description:
Proof: Let $z_{i}=x_{i}-y_{i} (1 \leqslant i \leqslant n)$.
Then $z_{1} \leqslant z_{2} \leqslant \cdots \leqslant z_{n}$, and $\sum_{i=1}^{n} i z_{i}=0$.
It suffices to prove: $\sum_{i=1}^{n} z_{i}[i \alpha] \geqslant 0$.
Let $z=\left(z_{1}, z_{2}, \cdots, z_{n}\right)$, $u=(1,2, \cdots, n)$,
$v=([\alpha],[2 \alpha], \cdots,[n \alpha])$.
For $i=1,2, \cdots, n-1$, let
$w_{i}=\left(-1,-1, \cdots,-1, \frac{i(i+1)}{(n+i+1)(n-i)}\right.$,
$$
\left.\cdots, \frac{i(i+1)}{(n+i+1)(n-i)}\right),
$$

where there are $i$ negative ones and $n-i$ terms of $\frac{i(i+1)}{(n+i+1)(n-i)}$.
It is easy to see that $\left(w_{i}, u\right)=0=(z, u)$.
First, we prove a lemma.
Lemma: There exist non-negative real numbers $c_{1}, c_{2}, \cdots, c_{n-1}$, such that
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} c_{i} w_{i}=z.
$$

Proof: We provide a method to sequentially determine $c_{n-1}, c_{n-2}, \cdots, c_{1}$.
Consider $z_{n}-z_{n-1} \geqslant 0$.
There exists a non-negative real number $c_{n-1}$ such that the difference between the $n$-th and $(n-1)$-th coordinates of $c_{n-1} w_{n-1}$ is $z_{n}-z_{n-1}$. Replace $z$ with $z-c_{n-1} w_{n-1}$, and we still have $(z, u)=0$, and
$$
z_{1} \leqslant z_{2} \leqslant \cdots \leqslant z_{n-1}=z_{n}.
$$

Next, consider $z_{n-1}-z_{n-2}$, and determine $c_{n-2}$ such that the difference between the $(n-1)$-th and $(n-2)$-th coordinates of $c_{n-2} w_{n-2}$ is $z_{n-1}-z_{n-2}$. Subtract $c_{n-2} w_{n-2}$ from $z$, and this process can be repeated to determine $c_{n-1}, c_{n-2}, \cdots, c_{1}$.
By the lemma, $(z, v)=\sum_{i=1}^{n} c_{i}\left(w_{i}, v\right)$.
It suffices to prove that for each $1 \leqslant i \leqslant n-1$, $\left(w_{i}, v\right) \geqslant 0$, i.e.,
$$
\sum_{j=1}^{i}[j \alpha] \leqslant \sum_{k=i+1}^{n} \frac{i(i+1)}{(n+i+1)(n-i)}[k \alpha].
$$

For each $k=i+1, \cdots, n$, let $q(k)$ be a positive rational number such that $q(k) \sum_{j=1}^{i} j=\frac{i(i+1) k}{(n+i+1)(n-i)}$. Choose a sufficiently divisible positive integer $N$ such that $N q(k) \frac{N i(i+1)}{(n+i+1)(n-i)}$ are all integers.
By the corollary, we have
$$
\sum_{j=1}^{i} N q(k)[j \alpha] \leqslant \frac{N i(i+1)}{(n+i+1)(n-i)}[k \alpha],
$$

i.e., $\sum_{j=1}^{i} q(k)[j \alpha] \leqslant \frac{i(i+1)}{(n+i+1)(n-i)}[k \alpha]$.
Summing over $k=i+1, \cdots, n$, we get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\left(\sum_{k=i+1}^{n} q(k)\right)\left(\sum_{j=1}^{i}[j \alpha]\right) \\
\leqslant \frac{i(i+1)}{(n+i+1)(n-i)} \sum_{k=i+1}^{n}[k \alpha].
\end{array}
$$

Finally, since
$$
\left(\sum_{k=i+1}^{n} q(k)\right)\left(\sum_{j=1}^{i} j\right)=\frac{i(i+1)}{(n+i+1)(n-i)} \sum_{k=i+1}^{n} k,
$$

we have $\sum_{k=i+1}^{n} q(k)=1$. Hence, $\left(w_{i}, v\right) \geqslant 0$, and the conclusion is proved.
informal_statement:
Example 3 Let $n$ be a positive integer, real numbers $x_{1} \leqslant x_{2} \leqslant \cdots \leqslant x_{n}$, $y_{1} \geqslant y_{2} \geqslant \cdots \geqslant y_{n}$, satisfy
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} i x_{i}=\sum_{i=1}^{n} i y_{i} .
$$

Prove: For any real number $\alpha$ we have
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}[i \alpha] \geqslant \sum_{i=1}^{n} y_{i}[i \alpha] \text {, }
$$

where, $[\beta]$ denotes the greatest integer not exceeding the real number $\beta$. ${ }^{[1]}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset Real

/- Example 3 Let $n$ be a positive integer, real numbers $x_{1} \leqslant x_{2} \leqslant \cdots \leqslant x_{n}$, $y_{1} \geqslant y_{2} \geqslant \cdots \geqslant y_{n}$, satisfy
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} i x_{i}=\sum_{i=1}^{n} i y_{i} .
$$

Prove: For any real number $\alpha$ we have
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}[i \alpha] \geqslant \sum_{i=1}^{n} y_{i}[i \alpha] \text {, }
$$

where, $[\beta]$ denotes the greatest integer not exceeding the real number $\beta$. ${ }^{[1]}$ -/
theorem inequalities_319027 {n : ℕ} (hn : 0 < n) (x y : ℕ → ℝ)
    (hx : MonotoneOn x (range n)) (hy : AntitoneOn y (range n))
    (h : ∑ i ∈ range n, (i + 1) * x i = ∑ i ∈ range n, (i + 1) * y i) :
    ∀ α : ℝ, ∑ i ∈ range n, x i * ⌊(i + 1) * α⌋ ≥ ∑ i ∈ range n, y i * ⌊(i + 1) * α⌋ := by

soln_description:
10. Solution: Let the distance between ports A and B be $x$ kilometers. The distance the second ship travels in 18 hours is $240 \times \frac{18}{24}=180$ kilometers, and the distance the third ship travels in 8 hours is $180 \times \frac{8}{24}=60$ kilometers. According to the problem, we have
$$\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x \equiv 0(\bmod 300) \\
x \equiv 180(\bmod 240) \\
x \equiv 60(\bmod 180)
\end{array}\right.$$

Since
$$\begin{array}{l}
(300,240)=60, \text { and } 60 \mid(180-0) ; \\
(300,180)=60, \text { and } 60 \mid(60-0) ; \\
(240,180)=60, \text { and } 60 \mid(180-60) ;
\end{array}$$

the system of congruences has a solution. Because
$$\begin{aligned}
300 & =2^{2} \times 3 \times 5^{2} \\
240 & =2^{4} \times 3 \times 5 \\
180 & =2^{2} \times 3^{2} \times 5
\end{aligned}$$

the original system of congruences is equivalent to
$$\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x \equiv 0 \quad\left(\bmod 5^{2}\right) \\
x \equiv 180 \equiv 4 \quad\left(\bmod 2^{4}\right) \\
x \equiv 60 \equiv 6 \quad\left(\bmod 3^{2}\right)
\end{array}\right.$$

We solve this using the Chinese Remainder Theorem. Here,
$$\begin{array}{c}
b_{1}=0, \quad b_{2}=4, \quad b_{3}=6 \\
m_{1}=5^{2}, \quad m_{2}=2^{4}, \quad m_{3}=3^{2} \\
m=5^{2} \times 2^{4} \times 3^{2}=3600 \\
M_{1}=\frac{3600}{5^{2}}=144, \quad M_{2}=\frac{3600}{2^{4}}=225 \\
M_{3}=\frac{3600}{9}=400
\end{array}$$

From $144 M_{1}^{\prime} \equiv 1\left(\bmod 5^{2}\right)$, i.e., $19 M_{1}^{\prime} \equiv 1\left(\bmod 5^{2}\right)$, we get $M_{1}^{\prime}=4$. From $225 M_{2}^{\prime} \equiv 1\left(\bmod 2^{4}\right)$, i.e., $M_{2}^{\prime} \equiv 1\left(\bmod 2^{4}\right)$, we get $M_{2}^{\prime}=1$. From $400 M_{3}^{\prime} \equiv 1\left(\bmod 3^{2}\right)$, i.e., $4 M_{3}^{\prime} \equiv 1(\bmod 9)$, we get $M_{3}^{\prime}=-2$. Therefore,
$$\begin{aligned}
x & \equiv 4 \times 225 \times 1+6 \times 400 \times(-2) \\
& \equiv-3900 \equiv 3300(\bmod 3600)
\end{aligned}$$

Since the distance between ports A and B does not exceed 5000 kilometers, the actual distance is 3300 kilometers.

Also,
$$\begin{array}{l}
\frac{3300}{300}=11 \\
\frac{3300}{240}=13 \frac{18}{24} \\
\frac{3300}{180}=18 \frac{6}{18}
\end{array}$$

Answer: The distance between ports A and B is 3300 kilometers. The first ship takes 11 days, the second ship takes 13 days and 18 hours, and the third ship takes 18 days and 8 hours.
informal_statement: 10. The distance between Port A and Port B does not exceed 5000 kilometers. Today, three ships depart from Port A to Port B at midnight simultaneously. Assuming the three ships sail at a constant speed for 24 hours a day, the first ship arrives at midnight several days later, the second ship arrives at 18:00 several days after that, and the third ship arrives at 8:00 a few days after the second ship. If the first ship travels 300 kilometers per day, the second ship travels 240 kilometers per day, and the third ship travels 180 kilometers per day, what is the actual distance between Port A and Port B in kilometers, and how long did each of the three ships travel?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 10. The distance between Port A and Port B does not exceed 5000 kilometers. Today, three ships depart from Port A to Port B at midnight simultaneously. Assuming the three ships sail at a constant speed for 24 hours a day, the first ship arrives at midnight several days later, the second ship arrives at 18:00 several days after that, and the third ship arrives at 8:00 a few days after the second ship. If the first ship travels 300 kilometers per day, the second ship travels 240 kilometers per day, and the third ship travels 180 kilometers per day, what is the actual distance between Port A and Port B in kilometers, and how long did each of the three ships travel? -/
theorem algebra_6871 (d : ℝ) (h : d ≤ 5000) (t1 t2 t3 : ℝ)
    (ht1 : t1 > 0) (ht2 : t2 > 0) (ht3 : t3 > 0)
    (h1 : d / 300 = t1) (h2 : d / 240 = t2 + 18 / 24) (h3 : d / 180 = t3 + 8 / 24) :
    d = 3300 := by

soln_description:
If there are prime numbers $p_{1}, p_{2}, \ldots, p_{n}$, then all prime divisors of the numbers $p_{1} p_{2} \ldots p_{n}+1$ and $p_{1} p_{2} \ldots p_{n}-1$ are distinct from the numbers $p_{1}, p_{2}, \ldots, p_{n}$.

## Solution

Suppose, on the contrary, that there are only finitely many such prime numbers, denoted by $p_{1}, p_{2}, \ldots, p_{n}$. The number $A=3 p_{1} p_{2} \ldots p_{n}-1$ does not divide the prime numbers $p_{1}, p_{2}, \ldots, p_{n}$ and gives a remainder of 2 when divided by 3. Therefore, among its prime divisors, there must be a number of the form $3 k+2$. This is a contradiction.
informal_statement:
Prove that there are infinitely many prime numbers that give a remainder of 2 when divided by 3.

#
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Prove that there are infinitely many prime numbers that give a remainder of 2 when divided by 3.

# -/
theorem number_theory_200431 : ∀ n, ∃ p > n, p.Prime ∧ p % 3 = 2 := by

By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we have

\begin{array}{c}
{\left[(x+y)^{2}+(z+x)^{2}+(y+z)^{2}\right]\left(4^{2}+8^{2}+10^{2}\right)} \\
\geqslant[4(x+y)+8(z+x)+10(y+z)]^{2} .
\end{array}
$$

Simplifying, we get $-11r$.
$$
54 x^{2}+41 y^{2}+9 z^{2} \geqslant-6 x y+18 z x+36 y z \text {. }
$$

When $x: y: z=1: 3: 7$, the equality holds.
Thus, the minimum value of $k$ is 1.

-6 x y + 18 z x + 36 y z . \\
\leqslant k\left(54 x^{2} + 41 y^{2} + 9 z^{2}\right) .

Then the minimum value of the real number $k$ is
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 6. For any real numbers $x, y, z$ not all zero, we have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
-6 x y + 18 z x + 36 y z . \\
\leqslant k\left(54 x^{2} + 41 y^{2} + 9 z^{2}\right) .
\end{array}
$$

Then the minimum value of the real number $k$ is -/
theorem inequalities_317661 (k : ℝ) :
    (∀ x y z : ℝ, (x ≠ 0 ∨ y ≠ 0 ∨ z ≠ 0) →
      -6 * x * y + 18 * z * x + 36 * y * z ≤
        k * (54 * x ^ 2 + 41 * y ^ 2 + 9 * z ^ 2)) ↔ k ≥ 1 := by

soln_description:
Solve: This is to find all odd primes $p$ such that $\left(\frac{3}{p}\right)=1$. By Theorem 5, we know
$$\left(\frac{3}{p}\right)=(-1)^{(p-1) / 2}\left(\frac{p}{3}\right)$$

It is evident that $p$ is an odd prime greater than 3. By
$$(-1)^{(p-1) / 2}=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
1, & p \equiv 1(\bmod 4) \\
-1, & p \equiv-1(\bmod 4)
\end{array}\right.$$

and
$$\left(\frac{p}{3}\right)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)=1, & p \equiv 1(\bmod 6) \\
\left(\frac{-1}{3}\right)=-1, & p \equiv-1(\bmod 6)
\end{array}\right.$$

we know that $\left(\frac{3}{p}\right)=1$ if and only if
$$p \equiv 1(\bmod 4), \quad p \equiv 1(\bmod 6) ;$$

or
$$p \equiv-1(\bmod 4), \quad p \equiv-1(\bmod 6)$$

From the system of congruences (10), we know that $p \equiv 1(\bmod 12)$, and from (11), we know that $p \equiv-1(\bmod 12)$. Therefore, 3 is a quadratic residue modulo $p$ if and only if $p \equiv \pm 1(\bmod 12)$. This implies that 3 is a quadratic non-residue modulo $p$ if and only if $p \equiv \pm 5(\bmod 12)$ (why).

For such a small number as 3, we can still use Lemma 2 directly, as in Theorem 3, to solve Example 3. Using the notation of Lemma 2, take $d=3$. We have
$$\begin{array}{ll}
1 \leqslant t_{j}=3 j3$, from the above discussion, we know
$$n=[p / 3]-[p / 6]$$

Therefore,
$$n=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
{\left[\frac{6 k+1}{3}\right]-\left[\frac{6 k+1}{6}\right]=k,} & p=6 k+1, \\
{\left[\frac{6 k-1}{3}\right]-\left[\frac{6 k-1}{6}\right]=k,} & p=6 k-1
\end{array}\right.$$

Thus, we have
$$\left(\frac{3}{p}\right)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
1, & p \equiv \pm 1(\bmod 12) \\
-1, & p \equiv \pm 5(\bmod 12)
\end{array}\right.$$

This yields the same result as above. However, for larger numbers, using the quadratic reciprocity law is more convenient and less prone to errors.
informal_statement: Example 3 Find all odd prime numbers $p$ for which 3 is a quadratic residue.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 3 Find all odd prime numbers $p$ for which 3 is a quadratic residue. -/
theorem number_theory_6388 (p : ℕ) (hp : Odd p ∧ Nat.Prime p) :
    ∃ x, x^2 ≡ 3 [MOD p] ↔ p ≡ 1 [MOD 12] ∨ p ≡ 11 [MOD 12] := by

informal_statement:
Given that $a, b, c$ are the roots of the polynomial equation $x^3 + ux^2 + (u-3)x - 1 = 0$, prove that:
\[
\sqrt[3]{a} + \sqrt[3]{b} + \sqrt[3]{c} = \sqrt[3]{6 - u - 3\sqrt[3]{u^2 - 3u + 9}}
\]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Given that $a, b, c$ are the roots of the polynomial equation $x^3 + ux^2 + (u-3)x - 1 = 0$, prove that:
\[
\sqrt[3]{a} + \sqrt[3]{b} + \sqrt[3]{c} = \sqrt[3]{6 - u - 3\sqrt[3]{u^2 - 3u + 9}}
\] -/
theorem algebra_5792 {a b c u : ℝ} (ha : a^3 + u*a^2 + (u-3)*a - 1 = 0)
    (hb : b^3 + u*b^2 + (u-3)*b - 1 = 0) (hc : c^3 + u*c^2 + (u-3)*c - 1 = 0) :
    a^(1/3) + b^(1/3) + c^(1/3) =
    (6 - u - 3*(u^2 - 3*u + 9)^(1/3))^(1/3) := by

soln_description:
1. **Identify the problem and given conditions:**
   - We have a non-zero polynomial \( P \) with non-negative real coefficients.
   - \( N \) is a positive integer.
   - \( \sigma \) is a permutation of the set \(\{1, 2, \ldots, n\}\).
   - We need to determine the least value of the sum \(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{P(x_i^2)}{P(x_i x_{\sigma(i)})}\) as \( x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n \) run through the set of positive real numbers.

2. **Initial observation:**
   - The sum \(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{P(x_i^2)}{P(x_i x_{\sigma(i)})}\) is to be minimized.
   - We start by considering the case when \(\sigma(i) = i\), i.e., the identity permutation.

3. **Evaluate the sum for the identity permutation:**
   - When \(\sigma(i) = i\), the sum becomes:
     \[
     \sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{P(x_i^2)}{P(x_i^2)} = \sum_{i=1}^{n} 1 = n
     \]
   - This shows that the sum is at least \( n \).

4. **Use the AM-GM inequality:**
   - By the Arithmetic Mean-Geometric Mean (AM-GM) inequality, we have:
     \[
     \sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{P(x_i^2)}{P(x_i x_{\sigma(i)})} \geq n \left( \prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{P(x_i^2)}{P(x_i x_{\sigma(i)})} \right)^{1/n}
     \]

5. **Simplify the product inside the AM-GM inequality:**
   - Consider the product:
     \[
     \prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{P(x_i^2)}{P(x_i x_{\sigma(i)})}
     \]
   - By the properties of polynomials with non-negative coefficients and the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we have:
     \[
     \sqrt{P(x_i^2)} \sqrt{P(x_{\sigma(i)}^2)} \geq P(x_i x_{\sigma(i)})
     \]
   - Therefore:
     \[
     \prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{P(x_i^2)}{P(x_i x_{\sigma(i)})} \geq \prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\sqrt{P(x_i^2)} \sqrt{P(x_{\sigma(i)}^2)}}{P(x_i x_{\sigma(i)})}
     \]

6. **Apply the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality:**
   - Using the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we get:
     \[
     \sqrt{P(x_i^2)} \sqrt{P(x_{\sigma(i)}^2)} \geq P(x_i x_{\sigma(i)})
     \]
   - Thus:
     \[
     \prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\sqrt{P(x_i^2)} \sqrt{P(x_{\sigma(i)}^2)}}{P(x_i x_{\sigma(i)})} \geq 1
     \]

7. **Combine the results:**
   - Combining the results from the AM-GM inequality and the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we get:
     \[
     n \left( \prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\sqrt{P(x_i^2)} \sqrt{P(x_{\sigma(i)}^2)}}{P(x_i x_{\sigma(i)})} \right)^{1/n} \geq n
     \]

8. **Conclusion:**
   - Therefore, the minimum value of the sum \(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{P(x_i^2)}{P(x_i x_{\sigma(i)})}\) is \( n \).

The final answer is \(\boxed{n}\)
informal_statement:
Let $P$ be a non-zero polynomial with non-negative real coefficients, let $N$ be a positive integer, and let $\sigma$ be a permutation of the set $\{1,2,...,n\}$. Determine the least value the sum
\[\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{P(x_i^2)}{P(x_ix_{\sigma(i)})}\] may achieve, as $x_1,x_2,...,x_n$ run through the set of positive real numbers.

[i]Fedor Petrov[/i]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Let $P$ be a non-zero polynomial with non-negative real coefficients, let $N$ be a positive integer, and let $\sigma$ be a permutation of the set $\{1,2,...,n\}$. Determine the least value the sum
\[\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{P(x_i^2)}{P(x_ix_{\sigma(i)})}\] may achieve, as $x_1,x_2,...,x_n$ run through the set of positive real numbers.

[i]Fedor Petrov[/i] -/
theorem inequalities_88730 {P : Polynomial ℝ} (hP : P ≠ 0)
  (hP1 : ∀ n : ℕ, P.coeff n ≥ 0) {N : ℕ} (hN : N > 0)
  (σ : Equiv.Perm (Fin N)) :
  IsLeast {∑ i : Fin N, P.eval (x i ^ 2) / P.eval (x i * x (σ i)) |
    (x : Fin N → ℝ) (hx : ∀ i, 0 < x i)} N :=

soln_description:
[Solution] Since $44 x \geqslant 86868$,
thus $x \geqslant\left[\frac{86868+43}{44}\right]=1975$.
Therefore, $x$ must be at least a four-digit number. On the other hand, if the number of digits $k \geqslant 5$ in $x$, then
$$
44 x-86868>4 \times 10^{k}-10^{5} \geqslant 3 \times 10^{k}>9^{k}
$$

Thus, $44 x-86868>p(x)$ (the product of $x$'s $k$ digits) leads to a contradiction, so $x$ must be a four-digit number.

From the given, the sum of the four digits of $x$, $S(x)$, satisfies $1 \leqslant S(x) \leqslant 36$. Therefore, $S(x)=$ 1, 8, or 27.
Clearly, $S(x)=1$ does not meet the requirements.

Since $0<p(x) \leqslant 9^{4}=6561$,
it follows that $x \leqslant\left[\frac{86868+6561}{44}\right]=2123$.
Among the numbers satisfying $1975 \leqslant x \leqslant 2123$ and making $S(x)=8$ or $27, p(x) \neq 0$, only $1989, 1998, 2114, 2123$ are valid. Upon inspection, only $x=1989$ has the product of its digits equal to $44 x-86868$, so $x=1989$ is the only solution to this problem.
informal_statement: 1. 25 Find all natural numbers $x$ that satisfy the following conditions: the product of the digits of $x$ equals $44x - 86868$, and the sum of the digits is a perfect cube.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. 25 Find all natural numbers $x$ that satisfy the following conditions: the product of the digits of $x$ equals $44x - 86868$, and the sum of the digits is a perfect cube. -/
theorem number_theory_260437 (x : ℕ) :
    (Nat.digits 10 x).prod = 44 * x - 86868 ∧ ∃ k, (Nat.digits 10 x).sum = k ^ 3 ↔ x = 1989 := by

informal_statement: 10. Let $a, b$ be two positive integers, prove: $\frac{\varphi(a b)}{\sqrt{\varphi^{2}\left(a^{2}\right)+\varphi^{2}\left(b^{2}\right)}} \leq \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}$ (where $\varphi(n)$ denotes the number of positive integers less than $n$ that are coprime to $n$, with the convention $\varphi(1)=1$)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 10. Let $a, b$ be two positive integers, prove: $\frac{\varphi(a b)}{\sqrt{\varphi^{2}\left(a^{2}\right)+\varphi^{2}\left(b^{2}\right)}} \leq \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}$ (where $\varphi(n)$ denotes the number of positive integers less than $n$ that are coprime to $n$, with the convention $\varphi(1)=1$) -/
theorem number_theory_215300 (a b : ℕ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) :
    (Nat.totient (a * b)) / Real.sqrt ((Nat.totient (a ^ 2)) ^ 2 + (Nat.totient (b ^ 2)) ^ 2) ≤
    Real.sqrt 2 / 2 := by

soln_description:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}} \arcsin \frac{3+\operatorname{ch} x}{1+3 \operatorname{ch} x}\right)^{\prime}= \\
& =\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{3+\operatorname{ch} x}{1+3 \operatorname{ch} x}\right)^{2}}} \cdot\left(\frac{3+\operatorname{ch} x}{1+3 \operatorname{ch} x}\right)^{\prime}= \\
& =\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}} \cdot \frac{1+3 \operatorname{ch} x}{\sqrt{(1+3 \operatorname{ch} x)^{2}-(3+\operatorname{ch} x)^{2}}} \cdot \frac{\operatorname{sh} x \cdot 3 \operatorname{ch} x-(3+\operatorname{ch} x) \cdot 3 \operatorname{sh} x}{(1+3 \operatorname{ch} x)^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+6 \operatorname{ch} x+9 \operatorname{ch}^{2} x-9-6 \operatorname{ch} x-\operatorname{ch}^{2} x}} \cdot \frac{3 \operatorname{sh} x \cdot \operatorname{ch} x-9 \operatorname{sh} x-3 \operatorname{sh} x \cdot \operatorname{ch} x}{1+3 \operatorname{ch} x}= \\
& =\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{8 \operatorname{ch}^{2} x-8}} \cdot \frac{-9 \operatorname{sh} x}{1+3 \operatorname{ch} x}=\frac{1}{8 \sqrt{\operatorname{sh}^{2} x}} \cdot \frac{-9 \operatorname{sh} x}{1+3 \operatorname{ch} x}=-\frac{9 \operatorname{sh} x}{8(1+3 \operatorname{ch} x)}
\end{aligned}
$$

## Problem Kuznetsov Differentiation 11-18

open Real Set

/- ## Task Condition

Find the derivative.

$y=\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}} \arcsin \frac{3+\operatorname{ch} x}{1+3 \operatorname{ch} x}$ -/
theorem calculus_148490 {f : ℝ → ℝ}
  (hf : f = λ x => (1 / sqrt 8) * arcsin ((3 + cosh x) / (1 + 3 * cosh x))) :

soln_description:
68. $\frac{x}{y}=3 ; \frac{x^{2}+y^{2}}{x+y}=5$.

By squaring both sides of the first equation term by term, we get:

$$
\frac{x^{2}}{y^{2}}=9 \text { and } \frac{x^{2}+y^{2}}{y^{2}}=10
$$

Comparing with the second equation gives:

$$
\begin{aligned}
10 y^{2} & =5(x+y) \\
2 y^{2} & =x+y
\end{aligned}
$$

but $x=3 y$, therefore, $2 y^{2}=4 y ; y=2 ; x=6$.
informal_statement: 68. Find two numbers, the ratio of which is 3, and the ratio of the sum of their squares to their sum is 5.
informal_proof:
Let the two numbers be \(x\) and \(y\). We are given two conditions:
1. The ratio of the numbers is 3: \( \frac{x}{y} = 3 \)
2. The ratio of the sum of their squares to their sum is 5: \( \frac{x^2 + y^2}{x + y} = 5 \)

First, we establish that \(y\) cannot be zero. If \(y = 0\), the expression \( \frac{x}{y} \) would be undefined, which contradicts the first given equation. Therefore, \( y \neq 0 \).

Next, we establish that \(x+y\) cannot be zero. If \(x+y = 0\), then \(x = -y\). Substituting this into the first equation, \( \frac{-y}{y} = 3 \), which simplifies to \( -1 = 3 \), a contradiction. Alternatively, substituting \(x=-y\) into the second equation, \( \frac{(-y)^2 + y^2}{-y+y} = \frac{2y^2}{0} \), which is undefined, contradicting the second given equation. Thus, \( x+y \neq 0 \).

From the first equation, \( \frac{x}{y} = 3 \), since \( y \neq 0 \), we can multiply both sides by \(y\) to get \( x = 3y \).

Now, we use the second equation, \( \frac{x^2 + y^2}{x + y} = 5 \). Since \( x+y \neq 0 \), we can multiply both sides by \(x+y\) to obtain \( x^2 + y^2 = 5(x+y) \).

We substitute \( x = 3y \) into this equation:
\( (3y)^2 + y^2 = 5(3y + y) \)
\( 9y^2 + y^2 = 5(4y) \)
\( 10y^2 = 20y \)

To solve for \(y\), we rearrange the equation:
\( 10y^2 - 20y = 0 \)
Factor out \(10y\):
\( 10y(y - 2) = 0 \)

This equation implies that either \( 10y = 0 \) or \( y - 2 = 0 \). Since we have already shown that \( y \neq 0 \), the only possibility is \( y - 2 = 0 \), which means \( y = 2 \).

Finally, we find \(x\) by substituting \(y=2\) back into the relation \( x = 3y \):
\( x = 3 \times 2 \)
\( x = 6 \)

Thus, the two numbers are \(x=6\) and \(y=2\).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 68. Find two numbers, the ratio of which is 3, and the ratio of the sum of their squares to their sum is 5. -/
theorem algebra_219461 {x y : ℝ} (h₀ : x / y = 3) (h₁ : (x ^ 2 + y ^ 2) / (x + y) = 5) :
    x = 6 ∧ y = 2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_219461 {x y : ℝ} (h₀ : x / y = 3) (h₁ : (x ^ 2 + y ^ 2) / (x + y) = 5) :
    x = 6 ∧ y = 2 := by
  have hy : y ≠ 0 := by
    by_contra h'
    rw [h'] at h₀
    norm_num at h₀
  have h2 : x + y ≠ 0 := by
    by_contra h'
    have h3 : x = -y := by linarith
    rw [h3] at h₁
    field_simp [show y ≠ 0 by exact hy] at h₁
    all_goals nlinarith
  have h2' : x = 3 * y := by
    have h3 : y ≠ 0 := hy
    field_simp [h3] at h₀
    linarith
  have h3 : x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 = 5 * (x + y) := by
    have h4 : x + y ≠ 0 := h2
    field_simp [h4] at h₁
    linarith
  rw [h2'] at h3
  have hy_val : y = 2 := by
    have h4 : y ^ 2 * 10 - 20 * y = 0 := by
      nlinarith
    have h5 : y * (y - 2) = 0 := by
      nlinarith
    cases' (mul_eq_zero.mp h5) with hy1 hy2
    · -- y = 0 is impossible from hy: y ≠ 0
      contradiction
    · -- y - 2 = 0 => y = 2
      linarith
  have hx_val : x = 6 := by
    rw [hy_val] at h2'
    linarith
  exact ⟨hx_val, hy_val⟩

soln_description:
15. Set
$$
f(n)=\left[\frac{n+1}{2}\right]+\left[\frac{n+2}{4}\right]+\cdots+\left[\frac{n+2^{i}}{2^{i+1}}\right]+\ldots
$$

We prove by induction that $f(n)=n$. This obviously holds for $n=1$. Let us assume that $f(n-1)=n-1$. Define
$$
g(i, n)=\left[\frac{n+2^{i}}{2^{i+1}}\right]-\left[\frac{n-1+2^{i}}{2^{i+1}}\right] .
$$

We have that $f(n)-f(n+1)=\sum_{i=1}^{\infty} g(i, n)$. We also note that $g(i, n)=1$ if and only if $2^{i+1} \mid n+2^{i}$; otherwise, $g(i, n)=0$. The divisibility $2^{i+1} \mid$ $n+2^{i}$ is equivalent to $2^{i} \mid n$ and $2^{i+1} \nmid n$, which for a given $n$ holds for exactly one $i \in \mathbb{N}_{0}$. Thus it follows that $f(n)-f(n-1)=1 \Rightarrow f(n)=n$. The proof by induction is now complete.
Second solution. It is easy to show that $[x+1 / 2]=[2 x]-[x]$ for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. Now $f(x)=([x]-[x / 2])+([x / 2]-[x / 4])+\cdots=[x]$. Hence, $f(n)=n$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$.
informal_statement:
15. (GBR 1) ${ }^{\mathrm{IMO6}}$ Let $[x]$ denote the integer part of $x$, i.e., the greatest integer not exceeding $x$. If $n$ is a positive integer, express as a simple function of $n$ the sum
$$

$$
\left[\frac{n+1}{2}\right]+\left[\frac{n+2}{4}\right]+\cdots+\left[\frac{n+2^{i}}{2^{i+1}}\right]+\cdots .
$$ -/

soln_description:
2. Since the left side of the equation is independent of $p$, it is actually required to prove that when $x>1$, $x^{4}+4^{x}$ is a composite number. Recalling the formula $m^{4}+4 n^{4}=\left(m^{2}+2 n^{2}+2 m n\right)\left(m^{2}+2 n^{2}-2 m n\right)$, this problem is not difficult to solve. Let $f(x)=x^{4}+4^{x}(x \in \mathbf{Z})$.

We only need to prove that for $x \geqslant 2, f(x)$ is a composite number. (In fact, when $x<0$, $f(x) \notin \mathbf{Z}$, and when $x=0$, $f(x)=1$ is not a prime number, and when $x=1$, $f(x)=5$.)
If $x=2 k\left(k \geqslant 1\right.$ is a positive integer), then $f(x)=(2 k)^{4}+4^{2 k}=4^{2} \times\left[k^{4}+4^{2(k-1)}\right]$ is a composite number.
If $x=2 k+1(k \geqslant 1$ is a positive integer $)$, then $f(x)=(2 k+1)^{4}+4 \times 2^{4 k}=\left[(2 k+1)^{2}+2^{2 k+1}+2^{k+1} \cdot\right.$ $(2 k+1)]\left[(2 k+1)^{2}+2^{2 k+1}-2^{k+1}(2 k+1)\right]$ is a composite number.
Thus, the original proposition is proved.
informal_statement: 2. (1977 Hungarian Mathematical Olympiad) Prove that for any prime $p>5$, the equation $x^{4}+4^{x}=p$ has no integer solutions.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. (1977 Hungarian Mathematical Olympiad) Prove that for any prime $p>5$, the equation $x^{4}+4^{x}=p$ has no integer solutions. -/
theorem number_theory_257950 (p : ℕ) (hp : Nat.Prime p) (h : 5 < p) :
    ¬∃ x : ℕ, x ^ 4 + 4 ^ x = p := by

soln_description:
1. Consider the polynomial \( f(x) = (x^2 + x)^{2^n} + 1 \) over the integers. We aim to show that \( f(x) \) cannot be factored into two non-constant integer polynomials.

2. First, observe the polynomial in the finite field \(\mathbb{F}_2\). In \(\mathbb{F}_2\), we have:
   \[
   (x^2 + x)^{2^n} + 1 = (x^2 + x + 1)^{2^n}
   \]
   because \( x^2 + x \equiv x^2 + x + 1 \pmod{2} \).

3. Suppose \( f(x) = (x^2 + x)^{2^n} + 1 = gh \) where \( g \) and \( h \) are non-constant integer polynomials. Reducing modulo 2, we get:
   \[
   \overline{gh} = (x^2 + x + 1)^{2^n}
   \]
   where \(\overline{g}\) and \(\overline{h}\) are the reductions of \( g \) and \( h \) modulo 2.

4. Since \( x^2 + x + 1 \) is irreducible in \(\mathbb{F}_2\), it follows that:
   \[
   \overline{g} = (x^2 + x + 1)^a \quad \text{and} \quad \overline{h} = (x^2 + x + 1)^b
   \]
   where \( a + b = 2^n \).

5. Returning to the integer polynomials, we write:
   \[
   g = 2g_1 + (x^2 + x + 1)^a \quad \text{and} \quad h = 2h_1 + (x^2 + x + 1)^b
   \]
   for some integer polynomials \( g_1 \) and \( h_1 \).

6. Substituting these into the original polynomial, we get:
   \[
   (x^2 + x)^{2^n} + 1 = (2g_1 + (x^2 + x + 1)^a)(2h_1 + (x^2 + x + 1)^b)
   \]
   Expanding and simplifying, we have:
   \[
   (x^2 + x)^{2^n} + 1 = (x^2 + x + 1)^{2^n} + 4g_1h_1 + 2g_1(x^2 + x + 1)^b + 2h_1(x^2 + x + 1)^a
   \]

7. Considering the binomial coefficients modulo 4, we note that the only binomial coefficients \(\binom{2^n}{i}\) that are not multiples of 4 are when \( i = 0, 2^{n-1}, 2^n \). Thus, taking the expression modulo 4, we get:
   \[
   (x^2 + x)^{2^n} + 1 \equiv (x^2 + x)^{2^n} + 2(x^2 + x)^{2^{n-1}} + 1 + 2g_1(x^2 + x + 1)^b + 2h_1(x^2 + x + 1)^a \pmod{4}
   \]
   Canceling terms and dividing by 2, we obtain:
   \[
   (x^2 + x)^{2^{n-1}} = g_1(x^2 + x + 1)^b + h_1(x^2 + x + 1)^a \pmod{2}
   \]

8. If \( ab > 0 \), then \( x^2 + x + 1 \) would divide \( (x^2 + x)^{2^{n-1}} \) in \(\mathbb{F}_2\), which is a contradiction since \( x^2 + x + 1 \) is irreducible. Therefore, one of \( a \) or \( b \) must be 0. Without loss of generality, assume \( a = 0 \). Then \( b = 2^n \).

9. This implies:
   \[
   g = 2g_1 + 1 \quad \text{and} \quad h = 2h_1 + (x^2 + x + 1)^{2^n}
   \]
   The degree of \( h \) is at least \( 2^{n+1} \), so the degree of \( g \) must be at most 0, making \( g \) a constant polynomial, which contradicts our assumption that \( g \) is non-constant.

10. Therefore, \( f(x) = (x^2 + x)^{2^n} + 1 \) cannot be factored into two non-constant integer polynomials.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement:
Show that for any positive integer $n$ the polynomial $f(x)=(x^2+x)^{2^n}+1$ cannot be decomposed into the product of two integer non-constant polynomials.

[i]Marius Cavachi[/i]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Show that for any positive integer $n$ the polynomial $f(x)=(x^2+x)^{2^n}+1$ cannot be decomposed into the product of two integer non-constant polynomials.

[i]Marius Cavachi[/i] -/
theorem algebra_31096 {n : ℕ} (hn : n > 0) :
    ¬∃ p q : Polynomial ℤ, p.degree > 0 ∧ q.degree > 0 ∧
      (X ^ 2 + X) ^ (2 ^ n) + 1 = p * q := by

soln_description:
9. From the given $\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}=1(a, b>0)$, we get $a \geqslant 1, b \geqslant 1, a+b=a b$, thus
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (a+b)^{n}-a^{n}-b^{n}=(a b)^{n}-a^{n}-b^{n}=\left(a^{n}-1\right)\left(b^{n}-1\right)-1 \\
= & (b-1)(a-1)\left(a^{n-1}+a^{n-2}+\cdots+1\right)\left(b^{n-1}+b^{n-2}+\cdots+1\right)-1
\end{aligned}
$$

By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality:
$$
\begin{array}{c}
\left(a^{n-1}+a^{n-2}+\cdots+1\right)\left(b^{n-1}+b^{n-2}+\cdots+1\right) \geqslant\left[(a b)^{\frac{n-1}{2}}+(a b)^{\frac{n-2}{2}}+\cdots+(a b)^{\frac{1}{2}}+1\right]^{2} \\
a b=(a+b)\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}\right) \geqslant\left(\sqrt{a} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{a}}+\sqrt{b} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{b}}\right)^{2}=4
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, $(a+b)^{n}-a^{n}-b^{n} \geqslant\left(2^{n-1}+2^{n-2}+\cdots+1\right)^{2}-1=\left(2^{n}-1\right)^{2}-1=2^{2 n}-2^{n-1}$.

$$

/- 9. Given positive numbers $a, b$ satisfying $\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}=1$, prove: for every positive integer $n$, we have

(a+b)^{n}-a^{n}-b^{n} \geqslant 2^{2 n}-2^{n-1} .
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_229807 (a b : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b)
    (h : 1 / a + 1 / b = 1) (n : ℕ) (hn : 0 < n) :
    (a + b) ^ n - a ^ n - b ^ n ≥ 2 ^ (2 * n) - 2 ^ (n - 1) := by

11. $-2 \frac{7}{12}$.
Since $(a b c d e f)^{4}=1$, and $a, b, c, d, e, f$ are all positive, we have $a b c d e f=1$.
Thus, $\frac{1}{a^{2}}=4 \Rightarrow a=\frac{1}{2}$.
Similarly, $b=\frac{1}{3}, c=\frac{1}{4}, d=2, e=3, f=4$.
Therefore, $(a+c+e)-(b+d+f)=-2 \frac{7}{12}$.

/- 11. Given positive numbers $a, b, c, d, e, f$ satisfy
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\frac{b c d e f}{a}=4, \frac{a c d e f}{b}=9, \frac{a b d e f}{c}=16, \\
\frac{a b c e f}{d}=\frac{1}{4}, \frac{a b c d f}{e}=\frac{1}{9}, \frac{a b c d e}{f}=\frac{1}{16} .
\end{array}
$$

Then the value of $(a+c+e)-(b+d+f)$ is
$\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_326232 {a b c d e f : ℝ} (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (hd : 0 < d) (he : 0 < e) (hf : 0 < f)
    (h1 : b * c * d * e * f / a = 4) (h2 : a * c * d * e * f / b = 9) (h3 : a * b * d * e * f / c = 16)
    (h4 : a * b * c * e * f / d = 1 / 4) (h5 : a * b * c * d * f / e = 1 / 9) (h6 : a * b * c * d * e / f = 1 / 16) :
    (a + c + e) - (b + d + f) = -2 - 7 / 12 := by

soln_description:
Answer: Only 15.

Solution: Since $a$ is a root of the equation $x^{11} + x^{7} + x^{3} = 1$, then $a^{11} + a^{7} + a^{3} = 1$.

If we factor out $a^{3}$ from the left side, we get $a^{8} + a^{4} + 1$ - this is the expression $s^{2} + s + 1$ for $s = a^{4}$, which we have seen in the formula for the difference of cubes $s^{3} - 1 = (s - 1)(s^{2} + s + 1)$. Multiplying the equation by $a^{4} - 1$, we get $a^{3}(a^{12} - 1) = a^{4} - 1$, from which, after transformations, we obtain $a^{15} + 1 = a^{3} + a^{4}$.

It remains to note that $a \neq \pm 1$ and $a \neq 0$, since these numbers are not roots of the original equation. Therefore, all powers of $a$ are distinct, so nothing other than 15 is the answer.

Remark: The number $a$ exists: the value of $x^{11} + x^{7} + x^{3}$ at $x = 0$ is 0, i.e., less than 1, and at $x = 1$ it is 3, i.e., greater than 1. By the Intermediate Value Theorem, somewhere on the interval $[0,1]$ it must equal 1.

informal_statement: 8. The number $a$ is a root of the equation $x^{11}+x^{7}+x^{3}=1$. Indicate all natural values of $n$ for which the equality $a^{4}+a^{3}=a^{n}+1$ holds.

theorem algebra_160029 (a : ℝ) (ha : a^11 + a^7 + a^3 = 1) (n : ℕ) :
    a^4 + a^3 = a^n + 1 ↔ n = 15 := by

soln_description:
1. Consider the given system of equations:
   \[
   \begin{cases}
   5^x - \log_2 (y+3) = 3^y \\
   5^y - \log_2 (x+3) = 3^x
   \end{cases}
   \]

2. Suppose \( x > y \). Then \( 3^x > 3^y \). This implies:
   \[
   5^y + \log_2 (y+3) > 5^x + \log_2 (x+3)
   \]
   This is a contradiction because if \( x > y \), then \( 5^x > 5^y \) and \( \log_2 (x+3) > \log_2 (y+3) \). Therefore, we must have \( x = y \).

3. Substituting \( x = y \) into the system, we get:
   \[
   5^x - \log_2 (x+3) = 3^x
   \]
   Simplifying, we obtain:
   \[
   5^x = 3^x + \log_2 (x+3)
   \]

4. To solve this equation, consider the function:
   \[
   f(x) = 5^x - 3^x - \log_2 (x+3)
   \]
   We need to find \( x \) such that \( f(x) = 0 \).

5. Evaluate \( f(x) \) at \( x = 1 \):
   \[
   f(1) = 5^1 - 3^1 - \log_2 (1+3) = 5 - 3 - \log_2 4 = 5 - 3 - 2 = 0
   \]
   Thus, \( x = 1 \) is a solution.

6. To determine if there are any other solutions, consider the behavior of \( f(x) \). The function \( 5^x \) grows exponentially, \( 3^x \) also grows exponentially but at a slower rate, and \( \log_2 (x+3) \) grows logarithmically. Therefore, \( 5^x \) will dominate the other terms as \( x \) increases.

7. The function \( f(x) \) is monotonically increasing for \( x > 1 \) because the derivative \( f'(x) = 5^x \ln 5 - 3^x \ln 3 - \frac{1}{(x+3) \ln 2} \) is positive for \( x > 1 \). This implies that \( f(x) \) can have at most one root.

8. Since \( x = 1 \) is a root and \( f(x) \) is monotonically increasing for \( x > 1 \), there are no other solutions.

The final answer is \( \boxed{ x = 1 } \) and \( y = 1 \).
informal_statement:
Solve in $ \mathbb{Z} $ the following system of equations:
$$ \left\{\begin{matrix} 5^x-\log_2 (y+3) = 3^y\\ 5^y -\log_2 (x+3)=3^x\end{matrix}\right. . $$

import Mathlib

/- Solve in $ \mathbb{Z} $ the following system of equations:
$$ \left\{\begin{matrix} 5^x-\log_2 (y+3) = 3^y\\ 5^y -\log_2 (x+3)=3^x\end{matrix}\right. . $$ -/
theorem algebra_87188 {x y : ℤ} (hx : 5^x - Real.logb 2 (y + 3) = 3^y) (hy : 5^y - Real.logb 2 (x + 3) = 3^x) :
    x = 1 := by

soln_description:
Solution. By Hölder, we deduce that
$$\left(\sum_{c y c} \frac{a}{\sqrt{2 b^{2}+2 c^{2}-a^{2}}}\right)\left(\sum_{c y c} \frac{a}{\sqrt{2 b^{2}+2 c^{2}-a^{2}}}\right)\left(\sum_{c y c} a\left(2 b^{2}+2 c^{2}-a^{2}\right)\right) \geq(a+b+c)^{3}$$

It remains to prove that
$$(a+b+c)^{3} \geq 3 \sum_{\text {cyc }} a\left(2 b^{2}+2 c^{2}-a^{2}\right)$$

Rewrite this one in the following form
$$3\left(a b c-\prod_{c y c}(a-b+c)\right)+2\left(\sum_{c y c} a^{3}-3 a b c\right) \geq 0$$
which is obvious (for a quick proof that the first term is bigger than 0, replace $a-b+c=$ $x$, etc). Equality holds for $a=b=c$.

Example 2.2.10. Suppose that $a, b, c$ are positive real numbers satisfying the condition $3 \max \left(a^{2}, b^{2}, c^{2}\right) \leq 2\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)$. Prove that
$$\frac{a}{\sqrt{2 b^{2}+2 c^{2}-a^{2}}}+\frac{b}{\sqrt{2 c^{2}+2 a^{2}-b^{2}}}+\frac{c}{\sqrt{2 a^{2}+2 b^{2}-c^{2}}} \geq \sqrt{3}$$

$$\frac{a}{\sqrt{2 b^{2}+2 c^{2}-a^{2}}}+\frac{b}{\sqrt{2 c^{2}+2 a^{2}-b^{2}}}+\frac{c}{\sqrt{2 a^{2}+2 b^{2}-c^{2}}} \geq \sqrt{3}$$ -/

informal_statement:
Show that $A B+C D=A D+B C$. Use the above to conclude that for some positive number $\alpha$,

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
A B=\alpha \cdot\left(\frac{A I}{C I}+\frac{B I}{D I}\right) & B C=\alpha \cdot\left(\frac{B I}{D I}+\frac{C I}{A I}\right) \\
C D=\alpha \cdot\left(\frac{C I}{A I}+\frac{D I}{B I}\right) & D A=\alpha \cdot\left(\frac{D I}{B I}+\frac{A I}{C I}\right) .
\end{array}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Show that $A B+C D=A D+B C$. Use the above to conclude that for some positive number $\alpha$,

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
A B=\alpha \cdot\left(\frac{A I}{C I}+\frac{B I}{D I}\right) & B C=\alpha \cdot\left(\frac{B I}{D I}+\frac{C I}{A I}\right) \\
C D=\alpha \cdot\left(\frac{C I}{A I}+\frac{D I}{B I}\right) & D A=\alpha \cdot\left(\frac{D I}{B I}+\frac{A I}{C I}\right) .
\end{array}
$$ -/
theorem algebra_608249 {A B C D I : ℝ} (hABCD : A ≠ 0 ∧ B ≠ 0 ∧ C ≠ 0 ∧ D ≠ 0 ∧ A * B + C * D = A * D + B * C ∧ I ≠ 0 ∧ A * I ≠ 0 ∧ B * I ≠ 0 ∧ C * I ≠ 0 ∧ D * I ≠ 0) :
    ∃ α > 0, A * B = α * ((A * I) / (C * I) + (B * I) / (D * I)) ∧ B * C = α * ((B * I) / (D * I) + (C * I) / (A * I)) ∧ C * D = α * ((C * I) / (A * I) + (D * I) / (B * I)) ∧ D * A = α * ((D * I) / (B * I) + (A * I) / (C * I)) := by

soln_description:
5. It is sufficient to prove the conclusion in the problem for a $3 \times 3$ grid. From this, it can be deduced that the common ratio of geometric sequences in any two adjacent columns is equal, i.e., the common ratio of all columns is equal.

Observe the table in Figure 3: the middle row is an arithmetic sequence, and each column is a geometric sequence.
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline$\frac{a-d}{p}$ & $\frac{a}{q}$ & $\frac{a+d}{r}$ \\
\hline$a-d$ & $a$ & $a+d$ \\
\hline$(a-d) p$ & $a q$ & $(a+d) r$ \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Figure 3
Since the top and bottom rows are also arithmetic sequences, we have:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\frac{a-d}{p}+\frac{a+d}{r}=\frac{2 a}{q}, \\
(a-d) p+(a+d) r=2 a q . \\
\text { Let } x=\frac{p}{q}, y=\frac{r}{q} . \text { Then } \\
(a-d) y+(a+d) x=2 a x y, \\
(a-d) x+(a+d) y=2 a .
\end{array}
$$

Let $x=\frac{p}{q}, y=\frac{r}{q}$. Then

Adding the above two equations and canceling $2 a$, we get
$$
x+y=x y+1 \Rightarrow(x-1)(y-1)=0 \text {. }
$$

Let $x=1$ (the case $y=1$ is similar), we get
$$
(a-d)+(a+d) y=2 a \Rightarrow y=1 \text {. }
$$

Thus, $p=q=r$, which is what we needed to prove.

Prove: The common ratios of these geometric sequences are all equal. -/

soln_description:
86.58. The main idea of the solution is to use the "non-evenness" of the function \( 1 /\left(1+x^{3}+\sqrt{1+x^{6}}\right) \), specifically:

\[
\begin{aligned}
& \text { of the function } 1 /\left(1+x^{3}+\sqrt{1+x^{6}}\right) \text {, specifically: } \\
& \int_{-1}^{1} \frac{d x}{1+x^{3}+\sqrt{1+x^{6}}}=\int_{-1}^{0} \frac{d x}{1+x^{3}+\sqrt{1+x^{6}}}+\int_{0}^{1} \frac{d x}{1+x^{3}+\sqrt{1+x^{6}}}= \\
& =\int_{0}^{1} \frac{d x}{1-x^{3}+\sqrt{1+x^{6}}}+\int_{0}^{1} \frac{d x}{1+x^{3}+\sqrt{1+x^{6}}}= \\
& =\int_{0}^{1}\left[\frac{1}{1-x^{3}+\sqrt{1+x^{6}}}+\frac{1}{1+x^{3}+\sqrt{1+x^{6}}}\right] d x= \\
& =\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\left(2+2 \sqrt{1+x^{6}}\right) d x}{\left(1+\sqrt{1+x^{6}}\right)^{2}-x^{6}}=\int_{0}^{1} 1 d x=1
\end{aligned}
\]

soln_description:
## Solution

Let's find the points of intersection:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y=3(1-\cos t)=3 \\
& 1-\cos t=1 \\
& \cos t=0 \\
& t=\frac{\pi}{2}+\pi n, n \in \mathbb{Z}
\end{aligned}
$$

We are interested in the interval \(0 < x < 6\pi\). Then the abscissas of the points of intersection will be:

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_fa23e2deef6f8d90c6d5g-17.jpg?height=1002&width=1014&top_left_y=1098&top_left_x=909)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& t=\frac{\pi}{2} \Rightarrow x=3\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\sin \frac{\pi}{2}\right)=\frac{3 \pi}{2}-3 \\
& t=\frac{3 \pi}{2} \Rightarrow x=3\left(\frac{3 \pi}{2}-\sin \frac{3 \pi}{2}\right)=\frac{9 \pi}{2}+3
\end{aligned}
$$

Calculate the area:

$$
S=\int_{\pi / 2}^{3 \pi / 2} 3(1-\cos t) \cdot(3(t-\sin t))' d t=
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =9 \cdot \int_{\pi / 2}^{3 \pi / 2}(1-\cos t) \cdot(1-\cos t) d t= \\
& =9 \cdot \int_{\pi / 2}^{3 \pi / 2}\left(1-2 \cos t+\cos ^{2} t\right) d t=\left.9 \cdot(t-2 \sin t)\right|_{\pi / 2} ^{3 \pi / 2}+9 \cdot \int_{\pi / 2}^{3 \pi / 2} \frac{1}{2}(1+\cos 2 t) d t= \\
& =9 \cdot\left(\frac{3 \pi}{2}-2 \sin \frac{3 \pi}{2}\right)-9\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-2 \sin \frac{\pi}{2}\right)+\left.\frac{9}{2} \cdot\left(t+\frac{1}{2} \sin 2 t\right)\right|_{\pi / 2} ^{3 \pi / 2}= \\
& =\frac{27 \pi}{2}+18-\frac{9 \pi}{2}+18+\frac{9}{2} \cdot\left(\frac{3 \pi}{2}+\frac{1}{2} \sin 3 \pi\right)-\frac{9}{2} \cdot\left(\frac{\pi}{2}+\frac{1}{2} \sin \pi\right)= \\
& =9 \pi+36+\frac{27 \pi}{4}+0-\frac{9 \pi}{4}-0=9 \pi+36+\frac{18 \pi}{4}=\frac{27 \pi}{2}+36
\end{aligned}
$$

Source — "http://pluspi.org/wiki/index.php/\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\� \%D0\%9A\%D1\%83\%D0\%B7\%D0\%BD\%D0\%B5\%D1\%86\%D0\%BE\%D0\%B2_\%D0\%98\%D0\%BD $\% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 82 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 5 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 3 \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 80 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 0 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{BB} \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 8 \mathrm{~B}+15-9$ "
